posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked: We’ve had a few different brands of snap ring pliers over the years and the one consistent feature they all seems to share is that they are easily broken by high-school students. We use snap rings of a few different sizes. Anyone know of a good, durable, relatively inexpensive brand/model/set? Thanks in advance!

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:
Buy once cry once!

Straight tip

Order Knipex Retaining Ring Pliers, 0.046 In Tip, 0 Deg, 46 11 A1 SBA at Zoro.com. Great prices & free shipping on orders over $50 when you sign in or sign up for an account.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
I have a pair I like. I will try to remember to take a picture of them next time I am at the build site.

The reality is the ones with small pins to get into FRC size snap rings are easily damaged by the inexperienced. I keep a set put up for that reason. I find the ones that have the non removable pins easier to use than the ones with replaceable pins.

+1 for the Knipex for almost any tool. You get what you pay for.

I think this is the one I have. It has the advantaged to work with both internal and external.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Hard to go wrong with Knipex, they make quality stuff. I will say that in general I vastly prefer using angled tipped snap ring pliers over straight tipped ones.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Nate_Laverdure:

Buy once cry once!

254 has bought these dozens of times and cried dozens of times (probably close to 100 pairs over the last 15 years?).

These will not last forever. You’ll be lucky to get a few years out of them, unless you have very careful users.

They are the nicest we’ve found, though.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked:
Same experience. Knipex def best we’ve found.

We buy from chads toolbox quite a bit

posts.name: NathanNFM
posts.cooked:
I have never had any problems with these and like how they cover pretty much all the bases with all the tip choices included and having an internal / external switch.

posts.name: Jack
posts.cooked: I personally own a pair of these and really like them, my only complaint is that the pack of individual tips/the tips themselves are easy to loose.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Alum, Volunteer, Mentor, & Dean’s List Finalist

posts.custom_user_title: Alum, Volunteer, Mentor, & Dean’s List Finalist

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
These inexpensive Vice-Grip pliers may be the kind your students break, but we’ve used these for many years and they are still not broken.  We use snap rings only occasionally, so our experience might not apply to a snap-ring-heavy team.  These take a little while to change between external and internal rings, but we use external rings almost exclusively, so the inefficiency is not a big negative for us.

If money is not really a concern, a set of the Knipex pliers mentioned above is certainly a higher-quality choice.

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
I’m hardly a power user of retaining rings, but I also found the Channel-Lock 926 to be nice to use (except for the loose tip storage). They come with smallish tip sizes that are likely to be useful with small shafts.

I haven’t used any of the two-piece sheet metal ones that I really liked, and maybe only one set was even satisfactory.

If the many-tools world of the Knipex is appealing (compared to a single tool with many tips), maybe the less-expensive Icon 57796 set (Harbor Freight) could work if 0.047 in tips are adequate for your rings. They appear to be thick cast or forged chromium-molybdenum alloy steel, which in theory could permit quite strong and stiff pliers. (Hopefully the Icon stuff is consistently tempered properly, and the tips are well formed?)

There is also the Quinn 63938 (Harbor Freight) with similar action to the Channel-Lock. I have used it, but not extensively, and it seemed adequate at the time.

link_counts.title: 926 6-inch Convertible Retaining Ring Pliers | Channellock, Inc.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
I had a pair of these same ones (and some other brands in the same style), and they have a really stupid failure mode after a while. The flippy switch mechanism that changes them from external to internal can fail, and the tips only spread about 1/4" when the handles are squeezed fully shut. I am keeping the Channel Lock pair around to rebuild whenever I care enough, but they’re on the bench for now.

I will honestly take the Harbor Freight interchangeable head mechanism design over the “flippy switch”, but I only buy dedicated external and internal pliers now. I need to find some I like with good replaceable tips.
